paper_title: Evolution of microstructure and strength of a high entropy alloy undergoing the strain-induced martensitic transformation

graphs.title: True stress–true strain (compression & tension) for four processed conditions of Fe38.5Mn20Co20Cr15Si5Cu1.5 (at.%) HEA
graphs.description: Figure 1: True stress vs. true strain curves for S1, S2, S3, S4 categories compressed to fracture in in-plane (IP/TD) and through-thickness (TT/ND) directions, plus a tension curve along RD for S3.
graphs.about_graph: Compares rate of work hardening and peak strength among four thermomechanical states: S1 (FSP, 150 RPM, dual-pass), S2 (FSP, 400 RPM, single-pass), S3 (rolled + annealed 1100 °C, 30 min), S4 (rolled + annealed 1100 °C, 10 min). All tests at ~10^-3 s^-1 and room temperature.

curves.curve_description: In-plane compression of S1; among highest strengths and hardening.
curves.about_curve: Dual-pass FSP (150 RPM) condition compressed along TD/IP.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher flow stress than S2/S3/S4 IP due to finer grains and higher stored energy from lower FSP heat input.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy, room temperature, quasi-static strain rate; true stress–strain format.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.076.

curves.curve_description: Through-thickness compression of S1; highest strength (≈1.9–2.0 GPa peak).
curves.about_curve: Dual-pass FSP (150 RPM) tested along ND/TT.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Typically the strongest of all curves; slightly higher than S1-IP indicating mild anisotropy.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same processing family and test conditions.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.080.

curves.curve_description: In-plane compression of S2; slightly lower hardening vs. S1.
curves.about_curve: Single-pass FSP at 400 RPM; higher thermal input than S1.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lower strength than S1 due to somewhat coarser microstructure.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.156–0.265.

curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Slightly stronger than S2-IP; below S1-TT.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same specimen family; true compression curve.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.020–0.078.

curves.curve_description: In-plane compression of annealed (30 min) plate; lowest strength set.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Lowest flow stress and hardening among all IP curves.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.181–0.283.

curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Slightly stronger than S3-IP due to mild directional effect.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.023–0.077.

curves.curve_description: In-plane compression of annealed (10 min) plate; strength between S1/S2 and S3.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Higher than S3 due to finer grains/greater stored energy; lower than FSP states.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.075.

curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Slightly above S4-IP; below S2/S1 TT.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.025–0.074.

curves.curve_description: Tension along RD for S3; elongation ~0.18 with lower flow stress vs compression.
curves.about_curve: Dog-bone tensile test of annealed (30 min) state along RD.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Only tensile curve in this figure; stresses lower than compression at the same strain.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same material family and temperature; true stress–true strain.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.027–0.074.

graphs.title: Appendix A1: True stress–true strain of Fe42Mn28Co10Cr15Si5 (at.%) HEA
graphs.description: Appendix Fig. A1: Curves for compression along IP and TT, and tension along IP (RD) for Fe42Mn28Co10Cr15Si5.
graphs.about_graph: Shows behavior of the earlier metastable HEA (without Cu) for comparison; tensile curve inset is zoomed for clarity.

curves.curve_description: Compression along in-plane/rolling direction; strong work hardening.
curves.about_curve: Baseline compression response of the prior alloy along IP/RD.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Slightly lower than TT/ND compression; higher than tension.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.021–0.076.

curves.curve_description: Compression along through-thickness/normal direction; slightly higher strength than IP/RD.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Shows mild anisotropy with highest compression strength of the three.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.024–0.070.

curves.curve_description: Tension along in-plane/rolling direction; lowest stresses and smaller strain range (zoomed inset).
curves.about_curve: Tensile response for comparison to compression in the same alloy.
curves.what_is_different_between_this_curve_and: Only tensile curve; lowest stress level for a given strain.
curves.what_is_common_between_this_curve_and_ot: Same alloy and temperature; true stress–true strain definition.

Kocks\u2013Mecking_hardening_parameters.comment: Parameters obtained by linear regression on θ vs σ in the strain window 0.004–0.006.
